description: On July 10, at approximately 4:00 p.m. a white man (mid 20s) in a red verizon hat rang my doorbell.  I did not answer the door, but I was home working downstairs.  A minute later, the same man began knocking on the door.  Again, I did not answer, as I was working downstairs.  Approximately one hour later, the same individual returned to my house, again rang the door bell and then proceeded to knock on my door.  Again, I did not answer.  Later that same day, on or around 6:45 p.m. as I was watering the plants in my front yard the same individual approached me and came on to my property.  He was the same white man appeared to be in his mid 20s, wearing a Verizon hat.  I noticed he was wearing a silver chain.  As he approached, I said “thank you but I’m not interested” assuming he was trying to sell me something.  He replied in an aggressive manner that he was not trying to sell anything, and asked if my husband was home, which gave me cause for concern as I was home alone and he had been at my house several times that day.  I asked him to please leave, that he had already been at my house twice already today and that I was not interested and asked me to leave.  I said this as I was walking to my front door.  He was very rude and dismissive, and said that I was wrong and that he had not been to my house that day.  I said yes, you rang the doorbell and knocked on the door two different times.  I again asked him to leave.  He then said that he had a special offer and that if I did not sign I would lose out on some benefit for my Verizon account, or something bad would happen to my account.  I told him to leave again and shut the door. I just wanted to have this reported somewhere because I have no idea who this person was, if they worked for Verizon, and the fact that they were at my house observing me and came three times in such a short period is very disturbing.  Also, he was extremely aggressive and unprofessional, and wanted to know if I was alone, which made me highly suspicious and very nervous.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) does require new approved processed gravel to be used when backfilling utility excavations unless the existing gravel has been tested and approved. Since most small openings require time for the existing gravel to be tested all openings use new gravel. Since no City inspector was present at the backfilling we reached out to National Grid who stated that they did not use existing gravel, and used new processed gravel. I did remind National Grid because of the strike they may bring in personnel outside of Boston who might not be aware of our new processed gravel requirement and to remind them of that requirement. If you want to discuss this further I can set up a meeting with National Grid. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
description: Contractors using old dirt to back full

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for submitting your concerns to the BTD. The job of all persons operating a vehicle, whether a motor vehicle or one powered by foot, is to be aware and cautious. The dense urban fabric of our City does not allow for careless operation of metal objects or the negligence to stop on a red light. Allowing right turns on Red lights across the parking lane and the cycle track is  very unsafe as it gives mixed cues to various approaches and do not allow for parallel pedestrian crossings to be on at the same time. Signal timing adjustments have been given to the contractor as part of the Beacon Street project in order to reduce the delays that most users will experience on the Beacon Street corridor.

The Colonnade Hotel received a delivery this morning at around 9:50am, I measured the noise of the delivery truck at about 80 ft from our lot line and the truck was at 75 dB. Furthermore, staff is often dumping recycled bottles and closing loud doors in their loading dock from 6-7am all days of the week (particularly weekends). I have also measured these incidents, they range from 60-70 dB. They are a frequent offender of the noise ordinance, and I understand they need to conduct business but they need to remember their back neighbors are residences. I'd appreciate anything that can be done to eliminate these offenses.
